title: Cate Blanchett oozes elegance in two beaded gowns during chic shoot
text:
She is an Academy Award winning actress and is regarded for her philanthropic work, so it's no surprise she's being honoured at the Women of the Year Awards.

Yet despite her mounting accolades, Cate Blanchett admitted during a chat with Harper's Bazaar that she isn't interested in playing a version of herself on-screen, in favour of delving into other people's perspectives.

Alongside the interview the Blue Jasmine star, 50, posed for an array of sensational snaps in eye-catching beaded gowns, including an incredible striped monochrome dress which she lifted into the air during the shoot.

No thanks! Cate Blanchett admitted during a chat with Harper's Bazaar that she isn't interested in playing a version of herself on-screen, in favour of delving into other people's perspectives

Cate stunned in the dress which was covered in pearl beading across the semi-sheer top half of the stunning garment, before flowing out into the striped, pleated skirt.

She teamed her dress with a pair of chic court shoes, and kept the attention on her clothing by forgoing any additional accessories.

The Armani Beauty ambassador sported a perfectly applied coat of make-up, including a flawless coat of foundation and a subtle smokey-eye look.

She styled her platinum tresses in an elegant up do, leaving some curled strands to frame her striking features as she posed for a selection of glamorous shots.

What a beauty! Alongside the interview the Blue Jasmine star, 50, posed for an array of sensational snaps in eye-catching beaded gowns

Cate admitted that she wouldn't like to play a character close to her own personality, she said: ‘I’m never interested in portraying myself. For me, selfishly, it’s always about trying to understand someone else’s perspective.'

'Often the further from my own experience and my set of values, the more fascinating it is. And the only way we can move forward is to learn from history.’

Cate, who has also been a powerful advocate for the rights of women through her commitment to the #MeToo and Time’s Up movements suggested that the feminist movement isn't making enough progress.

She said: 'We’re still talking about same-sex restrooms, we’re still talking about women in the military, we’re still talking about reproductive freedom. And how many years ago was that? It really has been Groundhog Day.’

As well as fighting for women's right, Cate is also heavily involved as as a Goodwill Ambassador for UNHCR, highlighting the plight of refugees.

She said: ‘When I came onboard, there were about 61 million displaced people around the world, and now there are over 70 million...

'And that’s in just a handful of years. The size and scale of the crisis is so overwhelming that it’s difficult to relate to.’

Read the full interview in the December issue of Harper’s Bazaar, on sale from 30 October
description: Cate Blanchett admitted during a chat with Harper's Bazaar that she isn't interested in playing a version of herself on-screen, in favour of delving into other people's perspectives.
